did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: Papers of Peter Wild 1989-2004
did.abstract: The Papers of Peter Wild consist of research conducted by Wild which explores the life and accomplishments of author,John C. Van Dyke

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: University of Arizona Libraries, Special Collections

accessrestrict.p: There are no restrictions on access to this collection.

prefercite.head: Credit Line
prefercite.p: Papers of Peter Wild (MS 389). SpecialCollections, University of Arizona Libraries.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Peter Wild is a noted writer of poetry and nonfiction prose. Wild is well-known for his literary works such as Cochise and Easy Victory. His poems have been published in numerous magazines, which include Ironwood, Chicago Review, and The American Poetry Review. Over the last decade Wild has become the foremost authority on John C. Van Dyke and the Mojave Desert. His contributions to this field include Daggett: Life in a Mojave Frontier Town; The White Heart of Mojave: an Adventure with the Outdoors of the Desert; and John C. Van Dyke: The Desert. Peter Wild has been a professor of English and Creative Writing at the University of Arizona since 1971.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into one series

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Collection consists of research conducted by Peter Wild which explores the life and accomplishments of John C. Van Dyke, author of The Desert. The collection is comprised of Peter Wild’s interviews, notes, correspondence, photographs, research, and poetry on Van Dyke and the Mojave Desert. The collection is organized chronologically by year. Within each year’s addendum the original order created by Wild has been maintained.

did.unittitle: Series I: 1989

scopecontent.p: 1989 begins the first year of extensive research conducted by Wild on Van Dyke. It includes the forward for the project, outlining the reasoning and methods behind Wild’s research. The first document and the subsequent addenda include interviews and notes regarding Renee S. House, director of the Gardner A. Sage Library at the New Brunswick Theological Seminary, John W. Beardslee, Professor Emeritus at the New Brunswick Theological Seminary, and an interview conducted with Philip L. Strong, Esq., the second cousin of John C. Van Dyke. Includes Wild’s notes to himself regarding his published and unpublished manuscripts on Van Dyke and an epilogue.

arrangement.p: This Collection is organized into one series: Research materials, 1989-, chronologically arranged.

Series I: 1990

scopecontent.p: The 1990 addendum sequence contains updated information on Wild’s Van Dyke research and his publications on Van Dyke for the first year. Also included are notes on Van Dyke in relation to his Reformed Church background and his Dutch heritage.

Series I: 1992

scopecontent.p: The 1992 addendum sequence includes updated information regarding the publication of John C. Van Dyke’s autobiography and publications by Peter Wild. Detailed Van Dyke family information is also present. Notes also detail Van Dyke’s faked public image and background information on The Brides of Christ. Bibliography included.

did.unittitle: Interviews and Notes Regarding John C. Van Dyke, 1992 Addendum February 26, 1992
Interviews and Notes Regarding John C. Van Dyke, 1992 Addendum August 30, 1992
Series I: 1993

scopecontent.p: Included in the 1993 addendum sequence is the publication status of the Van Dyke autobiography and Van Dyke research conducted by others. Article, The Trip Not Taken and responses are also included.

did.unittitle: Interviews and Notes Regarding John C. Van Dyke, 1992 Addendum May 20, 1993
The Journal of Arizona History: The Trip Not Taken: John C. Van Dyke, Heroic Doer or Armchair Seer? Spring 1993"
Interviews and Notes Regarding John C. Van Dyke, 1993 Addendum. Research Documents (Including correspondence) April-May 1993 "April-May 1993"
John C. Van Dyke: Our First Politically Correct Desert Writer. No date
Series I: 1994

scopecontent.p: This 1994 addendum includes: Mary Austin correspondence, Lawrence Clark Powell notes on Van Dyke, updated Van Dyke notes, information on the faked trip article, and the publication status of Van Dyke’s autobiography, Wild’s first trip to Daggett (location of Van Dyke’s brothers’ ranch), notes on Van Dyke’s references to Dwarf Deer, and attachments including correspondence and research documents. Contains a table of contents.

did.unittitle: Interviews and Notes Regarding John C. Van Dyke, 1994 Addendum (Pt.1) pgs. 1-262 August 30-31, 1994
Interviews and Notes Regarding John C. Van Dyke, 1994 Addendum (Pt.2) pg. 263 and attachments August 30-31, 1994
Series I: 1995

scopecontent.p: The 1995 addendum includes information on Theodore Strong Van Dyke and his son Dix, John C. Van Dyke’s older brother and nephew, including John C. Van Dyke’s trips to their ranch in Daggett. Also included is information on Peter Wild’s 1st, 2nd, and 3rd trips to Daggett and his trip to La Jolla. Included is a table of contents and bibliography.

Series I: 1996

scopecontent.p: The 1996 addendum includes Dix Van Dyke’s papers, Peter Wild’s fourth trip to Daggett and his second trip to La Jolla. It also includes information on the relationships between John C. Van Dyke and Peter Barker, Mary Austin, Mexico, and his brother Theodore. Includes a table of contents and bibliography.

Series I: 1997

scopecontent.p: The 1997 Sequence: The first addendum includes Peter Wild’s fifth trip to Daggett, information on John C. Van Dyke, Mexico, and Pittsburgh. Contains a comparison of inaccuracies in various reprints of The Desert as well as notes by Lawrence Clark Powell on the 1918 edition of The Desert. The second addendum includes more John C. Van Dyke correspondence, mapping of Theodore Van Dyke’s ranch in Daggett, Wild’s sixth trip to Daggett, and more information on May Beal. Both parts include a table of contents and a bibliography along with research documents and photographs.

Series I: 1998

scopecontent.p: The 1998 Sequence includes continuing research and correspondence regarding John C. Van Dyke, and a transcription of Recollections of Boy Hood Days in San Diego 1880-1995 by Dix Van Dyke. Also included is Sequence I and II, which contains numerous poems created by Peter Wild. Both sections of the 1998 addendum have a table of contents, bibliography, research documents, and photographs.

scopecontent.p: Included is updated information of John C. Van Dyke, Daggett, and projects, information on Edna Brush Perkins author of The White Heart of the Mojave, and Peter Wild’s poetry Sequence I, II, and III. The table of contents, bibliography, and appendix can be found in both Part I and Part II of the Addendum.

Van Dyke, Daggett, and Edna Brush Perkins as well as information on Wild’s trip to Smith River, and his 11th and 12th trip to Daggett. The poem sequence III and IV are included. Addendum 2000 contains a table of contents, bibliography, and appendixes.

Series I: 2003

scopecontent.p: This addendum contains: updated materials on John C. Van Dyke, Daggett, and Edna Brush Perkins, notes regarding the 18th trip to Daggett and a trip to Palm Springs, and Wild’s poetry, Sequence IV. Addendum 2003 also contains a table of contents, bibliography, and Appendixes, A-E. Appendix A chiefly includes correspondence and photocopied newspaper clippings. The majority of the correspondence includes email communication between Ann Jopenga and Peter Wild. Appendix B, Part 1 and 2 include Ann Jopenga’s notes on L.A. Times article of January 6, 2002, her notes regarding Marshall South, and her interview with Rider South in 2001. Appendix C includes a movie on CD of Marshall South’s family around 1945/46. Appendix D includes information on the Historic Daggett Garage and corresponding photographs taken on May 2, 2003. Appendix E includes photos from the 18th trip to Daggett May 11-21, 2003 and photographs from a trip to Palm Springs on December 19-27, 2003.
